comment.author: 98338006@N00
comment._content:
I think the word is 'lattice-work' : the skeleton of a house built with wood, and the open spaces filled with a mix of straw+loam, or staw+cement (or just cement). This probably was loam, from somewhere in the neighbourhood.  That was cheap. 
The broadening of the flights could be to protect the lower parts from rains, or maybe to just build more house on less ground.
In the east of France and surrounding regions in Germany and Belgium you still can see this type of buildings, well preserved.

comment._content: This is the "Rue saint Romain", and the house is still there. his.nicolas.free.fr/Monuments/Zoom.php?mnemo=RouenRStRomain1

comment.author: 34419668@N08
comment._content:
Dominoa: Just amazing to see the modern photo of this old street and its buildings, which all seem to be preserved! The children and the horse carriage are replaced by people of today and the house is decorated with flower pots. The flight of time...

Thanks for identifying and showing us this comparative picture!

/Anna B.

comment.author: 98338006@N00
comment._content:
that's fun, to see history well preserved.
Now about the children: my idea was that they were workers, employed in an 'atelier' (small business) there. Maybe someone can identify the type of clothing, an overcoat/dustcoat, IMO not a school-uniform. People there must have been too poor to send children to school.
